head.title: To Right the Wrongs of Slavery

hedline.hl1: To Right the Wrongs of Slavery

abstract.p: Rachel Osterman letter, replying to Glenn C Loury's May 29 article, says reparations for descendants of slaves is justified in view of nation's lack of a strong welfare state and equally disbursed money for education

block.p: Glenn C. Loury (Op-Ed, May 29) is right that the atrocities of slavery cannot be compensated by paying reparations to African-Americans. He is also right that America must eliminate racial inequities ''for the sake of our country.'' Yet the political climate is hostile to the most effective means of achieving social justice: a strong welfare state and equally disbursed money for education.

Glenn C. Loury (Op-Ed, May 29) is right that the atrocities of slavery cannot be compensated by paying reparations to African-Americans. He is also right that America must eliminate racial inequities ''for the sake of our country.'' Yet the political climate is hostile to the most effective means of achieving social justice: a strong welfare state and equally disbursed money for education.

Reparations, therefore, offer a step beyond President Clinton's expression of regret for the American role in slavery and a step toward a time when Americans will acknowledge the need for stronger equalizing institutions like improved school systems and increased public assistance.
